title: Top 7 Most Remote Irish Pubs in the World
socialTitle: Top 7 Most Remote Irish Pubs in the World
metaDescription: From Dublin to Dubai, Irish pubs exist all over the world -- often in the least expected places. Here are some of the most remote.
description: Known for their shamrock-inspired interiors and compulsory pints of Guinness, Irish pubs are a phenomenon that has spread far beyond the Emerald Isle. From Dublin to Dubai, drinking establishments dedicated to the tradition of good Irish craic exist all over the world â€” and often in the least expected places. Here's a look at a few of the worldâ€™s most remote Irish pubs.
heading: Top 7 Most Remote Irish Pubs in the World

summary.title: Top 7 Most Remote Irish Pubs in the World
summary.socialTitle: Top 7 Most Remote Irish Pubs in the World
summary.heading: Top 7 Most Remote Irish Pubs in the World
summary.description: From Dublin to Dubai, Irish pubs exist all over the world -- often in the least expected places. Here are some of the most remote.

image.alt: Namche Bazaar village in the morning, Everest region, Nepal

list.description: The Irish Pub is a landmark in Namche Bazaar, a Khumbu village in Nepal known as the gateway to the Himalayas. At its lowest point, the village has an elevation of 11,386 feet/ 3,440 meters, making this the worldâ€™s highest Irish pub. Popular with those looking to acclimatize to high altitude before attempting an Everest climb, the pub is adorned with international flags and a sign that reads â€œThere are no strangers here, only friends that havenâ€™t metâ€. This sentiment is apt, as the pub is well-known for its mountaineering camaraderie. Opt for a pint of Guinness by the fireplace, or for traditional Sherpa beverages including the millet-based alcohol â€‹tongba. From the bar stock to the pool table, everything in the bar arrived there via yak train or on the backs of Nepalese porters.

image.alt: Namche Bazaar village in the morning, Everest region, Nepal

list.description: The Dublin is located in Ushuaia, a Patagonian town nicknamed the â€œEnd of the Worldâ€ where the Andes Mountains meet the frigid waters of the Southern Ocean. It is the worldâ€™s southernmost Irish pub, and a popular drinking spot for those about to embark on Antarctic expeditions or for skiers enjoying the nearby slopes. Its exterior is modest, with a basic structure of green-painted corrugated iron. Inside, the dimly lit interior is made cozy by shamrock and leprechaun-themed memorabilia, while the bar serves the de rigueur pints of Guinness and shots of Jameson whiskey. One can also sample craft beers from the local Beagle Brewery, named after the Beagle Channel and HMS Beagle, the ship made famous by Charles Darwin.

Situated on Seoul Street in the capital of Ulaanbaatar, Dublin Irish Pub claims to be the first Irish pub in Mongolia. Today, Ulaanbaatar is a bustling metropolis whose population accounts for nearly half of the people in Mongolia. The success of the Dublin Irish Pub has seen an influx of Irish watering holes â€” so much so that the capitalâ€™s nightlife scene is dominated by Gaelic pubs. The original remains one of the best and most authentic, however, although purists will likely claim that the atmosphere is still a long way from that of a real Dublin boozer. Nevertheless, Dublin Irish Pub offers televised sport and cold pints of Guinness, accompanied by good European music. If you fancy making a night of it, youâ€™ll find sprawling Grandkhaan Irish Pub on the same street.

As one of the worldâ€™s fastest growing cities, the Ugandan capital of Kampala can hardly be considered remote â€” and yet, itâ€™s still off the beaten track for most travelers. As such, Irish pub Bubbles Oâ€™Learyâ€™s comes as something of a surprise â€” especially when one learns that much of the pub was actually imported from Ireland. In 2003, the pubâ€™s owner Nigel Sutton purchased the furniture from a condemned pub in Drogheda, County Louth and shipped the pieces (including the front door and the bar itself) to Africa. A born-and-bred Irishman, Sutton keeps the spirit of the Emerald Isle alive in his Kampala pub, with pub food favorites served alongside ubiquitous pints of Guinness at tables in the social beer garden.

image.alt: Kampala City Scape from High Vantage

list.description: In terms of remoteness, itâ€™s hard to beat The Irish Pub in TÃ³rshavn. With a name that translates as â€œThorâ€™s Harborâ€, TÃ³rshavn is the capital of the far-flung Faroe Islands â€” a rugged archipelago located halfway between Iceland and Norway in the middle of the icy Norwegian Sea. The Irish Pub is a beacon of warmth for those looking to escape the harsh Faroese weather. The bar serves iconic Irish beers from brands like Caffreyâ€™s and Bulmers, while kitchen specialties include Irish steak and traditional fish and chips. Thereâ€™s live sport on TV, and regular live music on weekends (with a focus on Celtic bands, of course). The pub is unique to TÃ³rshavn and decorated with memorabilia imported from Ireland.

image.alt: Torshavn, Stremnoy island, Faroe Islands, Denmark. View over the city at dusk.

list.description: Located on the riverbank in the southern Cambodian city of Kampot, Oh Neilâ€™s is a favorite spot for expats and travelers. The pubâ€™s traditional bamboo exterior blends in with its exotic surroundingsâ€‹ but contrasts with the authentic Irish atmosphere inside. Here, shamrock decor vies for space alongside classic rock memorabilia, while the soundtrack harks back to the rock nâ€™ roll heyday of the 70s and 80s. Alongside Irish staples, the bar serves local and imported craft beers, while the menu includes global offerings ranging from curry to nachos. This cosmopolitan revamp of the traditional Irish pub goes well with Oh Neilâ€™s setting in the heart of Kampot, a city known for blending South East Asian culture with colonial French architecture.

Paddyâ€™s Irish Pub claims to be the highest Irish-owned pub in the world, and at 11,156 feet/ 3,400 meters, itâ€™s not far behind the pub in Namche Bazaar in terms of elevation. The pub is situated in Cusco, one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the Americas and the gateway for Machu Picchu. In an area of great scenic and architectural beauty, Paddyâ€™s Irish Pub offers a taste of Ireland with a bar roster that includes Guinness, Jameson and several Irish ales. The pubâ€™s food is similarly authentic, featuring Gaelic staples ranging from shepherdâ€™s pie to all-day Irish breakfast. Itâ€™s also possible to sample Cuscoâ€™s local culture at Paddyâ€™s Irish Pub. The bar serves Peruvian pisco sours, while the buildingâ€™s architecture evokes the Spanish colonial era.

image.alt: Steep cobblestone street with stairs built into sidewalks leading up to white arch in historic Cusco, Peru, along Cuesta de Santa Ana
